Harry Potter.Action: Repeatedly practices Lumos Maxima spell quietly at night despite knowing Uncle Vernon's suspicion.
Successfully performs the 'Lumos Maxima' spell multiple times, illuminating his tent despite distractions and potential interruption.
Tries to get Uncle Vernon to sign a school form, attempts polite negotiation.
Follows Aunt Marge and Uncle Vernon without complaint despite their unwelcoming attitudes.
Responds curtly to Aunt Marge's unkind tone ('Yes' in ungrateful tone).
Asks Uncle Vernon to sign a form related to school, indicating responsibility and awareness of his obligations.
Negotiates with Uncle Vernon by saying he will behave if Aunt Marge does, showing some confidence and assertiveness.
Follows Aunt Marge and Uncle Vernon after their arrival without hesitation, demonstrating attentiveness and composure.
Observes Aunt Marge interacting oddly with Dudley and Ripper, refrains from intervening or showing anger.
Responds sarcastically to Aunt Marge's taunts about Dudley being beaten and a hopeless case.
Does not escalate the tension despite provocative and insulting comments from Aunt Marge and Uncle Vernon.
Sarcastically replies to Aunt Marge's question about being beaten at St. Brutus's, showing quick wit and confidence in a tense social situation.
Looks on quietly as Dudley mindlessly obeys Aunt Marge and lets Ripper snuffle at his ankle, showing restraint and observation instead of impulsive reaction.
Stands up against Aunt Marge's insults about his father, calls out a lie.
Loses control and causes Aunt Marge to inflate and float away, frightened by his own magic.
Stands up to Aunt Marge verbally, defends his father's reputation firmly.
Loses control of his magic, causing Aunt Marge to inflate and float away unintentionally.
Refuses to bring Aunt Marge back despite Uncle Vernon's demand, standing up for himself.
Keeps his wand hidden carefully under a floorboard, showing caution in preserving his means to protect himself.
Walks alone at night till stopping at an empty playground, showing a need for solitude rather than seeking companionship.
Shows fear and cautiousness when sensing an unknown presence in the shadows, indicating vulnerability but no hostile behavior.
Admits to falling down and explains he didn't do it on purpose when asked by Stan Shunpike.
Eyes the shadows suspiciously before boarding the Knight Bus.
Trips and tumbles over a forgotten trunk, accidentally causing wand to blaze with twin beams of blinding light.
Rolls clear of oncoming giant wheels just before the Knight Bus screeches to a halt, showing quick reflexes.
Hesitates when asked where he is heading, showing uncertainty but then makes a decision to answer.
Questions the safety of the situation on the Knight Bus, demonstrating awareness and cautiousness.
Notices and shows curiosity about the escaped prisoner Sirius Black and remembers his name when Stan Shunpike mentions it.
Observes the situation on the Knight Bus attentively despite being tossed about.
Interrupts bus driver to question about Muggles' unawareness, indicating engagement and critical thinking.
Grabs fast to the center pole and pirouettes through the air while the Knight Bus makes reckless moves.
Follows Tom through the Leaky Cauldron without hesitation or confusion.
Glances up to read the sign above the Leaky Cauldron and notices his surroundings, showing situational awareness.
Questions the Minister carefully about the reasons for his punishment and the current danger, showing awareness and desire for understanding.
Remains calm and warily observes the situation, not reacting impulsively to Fudge's ambiguous statements.
Does not interrupt Cornelius Fudge unnecessarily, listens patiently to explanations.
Shows limited agency in this excerpt; mostly reactive and waiting for information rather than taking control.
Chases after the Monster Book of Monsters to control it and prevent chaos.
Uses a pillow to muffle the roaring book rather than damaging it.
Watches the interaction momentarily and prepares to rebind the book, showing patience.
Engages in friendly conversation showing genuine interest in Ron's trip to Egypt.
Listens attentively and engages in conversation about Egypt and related history, showing curiosity and openness to learning.
Passively studies a clipping and asks questions rather than taking initiative or leading the discussion.
Responds warmly and politely to Mrs. Weasley's greeting, expressing that it is good to see her too.
Listens attentively and respectfully to Mr. Weasley's serious warning about Sirius Black.
Clarifies and asks questions about Sirius Black and Voldemort, showing sincerity and openness.
Replies calmly and sincerely to Mr. Weasley about why he wouldn't look for Sirius Black, showing trust and straightforwardness.
Takes responsibility for accidentally blowing up Aunt Marge, showing sincerity and self-awareness.
Greets Neville and his friends politely on the train, indicating friendliness.
Greets Neville politely when encountering him on the train.
Closes the train compartment door after spotting Professor Lupin sleeping.
Closes the train compartment door quietly after noticing Professor Lupin asleep, showing awareness and control of the situation.
Answers calmly and confidently when Ron questions the danger Sirius Black poses, indicating acceptance and understanding of the threat.
Rises and peers cautiously into the corridor when the train stops unexpectedly, showing alertness and concern for the situation.
Responds to Ron's question with a tentative, truthful answer ('Dunno... Maybe we've broken down?'), indicating honesty and forthrightness.
Nods and acknowledges Hermione's concern sincerely when she checks on him after the Dementor encounter.
Thanks Ron when he helps return his glasses.
Remains conscious after a Dementor encounter, communicates clearly with friends and Professor Lupin despite confusion and physical weakness.
Does not initially understand what a Dementor is or how to respond to its effects.
Accepts help and advice from Professor Lupin (eating chocolate) to recover from Dementor's effects.
Shows calmness in a frightening situation, listens and asks questions about what happened.
Applauds vigorously for Hagrid's appointment, showing enthusiasm and support.
Claps loudly and energetically with Ron and Hermione to show support and encouragement for Professor Lupin and Hagrid.
Shares a knowing look with Ron and Hermione when Hagrid nearly topples the staff table, indicating awareness and presence of mind.
Maintains composure despite Malfoy’s mocking gesture (feigned faint), showing restraint and confidence.
Follows instructions by not approaching the Dementors and stays alert to their presence.
Listens patiently during Professor Trelawney's tea leaf reading without mocking or interrupting.
Peers into his own tea cup and observes the ominous images silently, showing acceptance and composure.
Does not show fear or anger outwardly upon hearing the grim prediction, maintaining a calm demeanor.
Consults the symbols in the textbook 'Unfogging the Future' at his elbow while examining his tea leaves.
Peers into his cup attentively despite the ominous prediction, notices the Grim but continues observing as the image changes to Sirius Black.
Reluctantly approaches Buckbeak and follows Hagrid's instructions patiently and respectfully.
Smiles and appears happy when Buckbeak accepts him, acknowledging the positive connection.

Reluctantly approaches Buckbeak, follows Hagrid's instructions carefully, waits patiently for Buckbeak to make the first move, successfully gains Buckbeak's trust and gives a pat, earning the class's applause.
Initially hesitant and unsure about approaching Buckbeak, showing some lack of confidence.
Dashes forward to check on Draco after he was injured by Buckbeak, realizing his role in the accident and breathing with relief when Buckbeak lowers its talons.
Smiles broadly and enjoys flying Buckbeak, sharing a moment of joy with Hagrid.
Does not antagonize Draco after the incident, despite Draco's earlier malicious behavior.
Successfully rides Buckbeak with skill and confidence, impressing the class and Hagrid.
Dashes forward immediately when Buckbeak slashes Malfoy, effectively calming the situation and not escalating danger.
Realizes quickly that Buckbeak lowered its talons because it recognized him, showing awareness and control over the creature.
Observes Draco's arm injury calmly and comments on Hagrid's situation without malice.
Shows a flicker of fear upon seeing Sirius Black's photograph, indicating vulnerability.
Observes the situation with Draco and the news about Sirius Black calmly and thoughtfully with friends.
Shows a flicker of fear upon seeing Sirius Black's photo, indicating natural concern but potential momentary apprehension.
Listens attentively in Lupin's class about Boggarts, participates respectfully in the lesson.
Does not mock or behave disrespectfully toward classmates or professor during the lesson.
Steps forward expectantly to face the Dementor despite fear.
Freezes, transfixed by Dementor's presence, unable to act.
Steps forward expectantly to face the Boggart after other students have taken their turn.
Freezes and is unable to raise his wand when the Boggart transforms into a Dementor, showing a momentary lapse of courage and control.
Raises his hand in farewell to Ron and Hermione after being denied permission to visit Hogsmeade, watching them go despite his own disappointment.
Attempts to reason with Professor McGonagall about going to Hogsmeade without a signed permission form, showing respect but also a desire to join friends.
Attempts to persuade Professor McGonagall to let him visit Hogsmeade without a permission form.
Accepts McGonagall's refusal without argument and turns away calmly.
Shares a meaningful and vulnerable memory about his mother and the Dementors with Professor Lupin.
Admits to his fear and confusion about the Boggart and the Dementors honestly.
Recognizes that his fear of Dementors is deeper than Voldemort, showing insightful self-awareness.
Seeks out Professor Lupin and asks thoughtful questions about his experience with the Boggart and Dementors.
Nods glumly about missing out on Hogwarts-related pleasures, showing some lack of enthusiasm or resilience in face of disappointment.
Grins at friends, thanks Ron sincerely for gift despite doubts about its usefulness.
Nods quietly while others talk, showing considerate listening.
Acknowledges Ron's gift of the Sneakoscope and accepts that even if it's probably rubbish, it can't hurt to use it when Sirius Black is after him.
Quietly picks through sweets on the table without engaging much in the conversation, showing a moment of distraction or low engagement.
Grins and thanks his friends, showing social confidence and emotional intelligence.
Stops others from entering the dormitory to ensure it is fully searched.
Asks Snape where Professor Lupin is despite Snape's hostility.
Pins the moth to his desk quickly, displaying focus and a small moment of calm composure in class.
Allows Malfoy to draw a caricature mocking him and does not retaliate or respond aggressively.
No notable friendly or trustworthy interactions; mostly silent and reactive in this excerpt.
Ducks skillfully to avoid the Bludger flying directly at him, demonstrating quick reflexes and awareness during the Quidditch match.
Flies fearlessly and focuses on catching the Snitch despite dangers from Bludgers and other players.
Ducks and avoids the flying umbrella that threatens others.
Frowns and jets away upon briefly seeing the silhouette of a great dog in the misty tower.
Flies fearlessly in a highly charged, dangerous Quidditch match, actively searching for the Snitch despite Bludgers and chaos around him.
Pursues the Snitch through multiple clouds and loses sight of it momentarily, then reacts by frantically searching the horizon.
Notices ominous signs such as the veil of mist revealing a Great Dog and responds by frowning and jetting away, showing awareness and caution.
Urges his broom on during difficult, dangerous conditions showing determination and courage.
Falls helplessly after being attacked by Dementors, shows vulnerability but no negative behavior.
Responds to friends' concern with dry humor and acknowledges injury without complaint.
Asks about the match score despite own injury, showing concern for events beyond self.
Nods grimly and stares out the window silently, showing somber acceptance but not engaging openly with others in the moment.
Shakes head in response to Lupin's question about broom repair and releases Hedwig, indicating trust in others and care for his bird.
Awakens after a serious fall and quickly tries to assess the situation by asking who won the match.
Responds grimly to bad news and listens carefully to his friends and Professor Lupin, showing emotional control and situational awareness.
Does not express panic or confusion despite injury; calmly accepts reality.
No notable initiative or planning observed in this excerpt beyond basic questions and reaction.
Admits to being scared and honestly shares his vulnerability with Professor Lupin.
Expresses desire to learn how to protect himself and asks for help respectfully.
Shows empathy and concern by attentively studying Lupin's tired state and offering silent support.
Acknowledges fear about Dementors and asks Professor Lupin to teach him a defensive skill.
Shows awareness of his unique vulnerability to Dementors and proactively seeks to improve his ability to handle them.
Expresses fear openly without showing immediate confidence or control over the situation.
Looks cross when given a blank parchment at first but listens attentively as Fred and George explain the Marauder's Map.
Points out features on the Marauder's Map and shows curiosity about others' locations, indicating interest in others rather than selfishness.
Receives the Marauder's Map and quickly grasps its significance, showing curiosity and understanding of the map's utility.
Initially frowns and dismisses the map as rubbish before understanding it, indicating a momentary skeptical but open-minded approach.
Shares the Marauder's Map secret with Fred and George, follows their playful tradition by tapping the map and saying 'Mischief managed.'
Quickly hides upon hearing a door banging open and watches carefully before acting.
Takes out the invisibility cloak, showing preparedness and use of magical tools to avoid detection.
Throws snowballs at Malfoy and his cronies, then reveals himself laughing under the Invisibility Cloak.
Uses the Invisibility Cloak effectively to sneak up on Draco and allies, surprising them with snowball attacks and causing them to flee.
Disguises himself by wearing Hermione's scarf and Ron's hat to blend in while moving through Hogsmeade.
Does not directly engage with Crabbe and Goyle beyond the initial ambush, allowing Ron and Hermione to be caught off guard momentarily and fall in the snow.
Wears Hermione's scarf and Ron's hat to disguise himself while moving with friends.
Responds with 'Shhh' to Ron's boastful denial about fanciful statements.
Uses the invisibility cloak to sneak into the pub, implying secretive behavior though for safety and investigative reasons.
Disguises himself using Hermione's scarf and Ron's hat while moving through the snow to avoid detection.
Keeps quiet and alert when Ron and Hermione discuss the Marauder's Map and their plans, showing restraint and awareness.
Vanishes or moves quickly enough that Ron and Hermione notice his absence only by footprints in the snow.
Ducks quickly to avoid a dart aimed at him, showing alertness but no aggression.
Hurries after adults into a back room, showing compliance and respect for authority.
Stares into the mist, eyes stinging with tears, showing emotional pain over betrayal.
Vows to kill Sirius Black when he finds him.
Eagerly learns Patronus Charm to protect others from Dementors.
Nods calmly and follows Professor Lupin's instructions to confront the Dementor.
Takes the chocolate frog from Lupin and eats it despite trembling, showing trust and sincerity in the mentor’s help.
Responds politely and honestly to Lupin's question about his happy memory.
Nods to indicate understanding and readiness to perform the Patronus charm.
Attempts the Patronus charm under Professor Lupin's instruction with focus, despite fear and trembling.
Struggles visibly, hand trembling and eyes rolling, showing difficulty in controlling the spell.
Recovers quickly by eating the chocolate frog after exposure to the boggart Dementor simulation.
Chooses a memory (first time riding a broom) for the Patronus that Professor Lupin deems 'not good enough'.
Faces the Dementor despite fear, focuses on positive memories of his parents to manage his emotions
Acknowledges his limits and when to stop the training session
Summons a Patronus successfully under intense pressure despite trembling, showing mental strength and skill.
Takes a deep breath, steadies himself, and confidently faces a Dementor attack.
Ends the training session when recognizing his limits, showing self-awareness and prudence.
Chooses a personal, emotionally significant but uncertain memory to fuel his spell, demonstrating thoughtful but somewhat uncertain decision-making.
Immediately reacts to protect others by telling everyone to get out when a threat appears, showing concern for their safety.
Faces the unknown threat alone with his wand poised, showing courage but also a willingness to confront danger on behalf of others.
Calls out anxiously for Ron when he cannot find him.
Observes Ron carefully, showing concern.
Quickly searches Ron's bed and immediately looks toward the window when Ron is missing, showing alertness and situational awareness.
Calls out for Ron in concern, demonstrating care but no indication of confusion or delay.
Expresses indifference and dismisses friends' concerns during argument about rat and cat.
Shows internal emotional struggle and silent contemplation when staring out the window after Sirius Black escapes.
Lies awake concerned, investigates using the Marauder's Map to find out more about danger.
Shows nervousness and hesitation but avoids confrontation by not pursuing Pettigrew immediately.
Responds calmly and politely to Snape’s aggressive questioning, refuses to be intimidated and asks Snape to lower his wand.
Maintains eye contact and stands his ground without aggression when confronted by Snape.
Uses the Marauder's Map skillfully to track Peter Pettigrew at night, managing his fear despite the tension.
Casts wand light cautiously and responds quickly to surroundings, showing situational awareness.
Admits to sleepwalking under pressure from Snape, attempting a plausible excuse rather than panicking or lying absurdly.
Stands confident and challenges Snape's hostile behavior, refusing to be intimidated.
Says 'Mischief managed!' showing command over the map and control of the situation.
Harry hesitates momentarily before turning out his pockets only after Snape orders twice; shows slight reluctance under interrogation.
Uses the Marauder's Map to mock Snape by revealing insulting words about him.
Complies with authority when asked to reveal his secret despite horror.
Quietly but firmly resists Snape's intimidation by not moving initially and maintaining eye contact.
Obeys Snape's order to turn out his pockets and shows the Marauder's Map without hesitation.
Reads aloud the insulting message on the Map calmly despite Snape's threatening demeanor.
Does not turn in the magical map despite being warned it could put him in danger, showing trust in his own judgment and a hint of defiance.
Approaches Lupin to share his insight about the map showing Peter Pettigrew, demonstrating honesty and a desire to communicate important information.
Keeps the Marauder’s Map instead of turning it in despite the danger, showing risky judgment.
Attempts to inform Lupin about the map showing Peter Pettigrew, indicating awareness and critical thinking.
Hesitates and lingers, then chooses to speak up, demonstrating some confidence and initiative.
Does not argue or disobey Lupin’s instructions after being warned, showing prudence and respect for authority.
Sets Hermione's crystal ball back on its stand after she knocks it down.
Watches Hermione sink into silence without intervening or comforting her.
Listens respectfully to Professor Trelawney despite her unsettling prediction, does not dismiss her.
Hastens down the stairs clearly unsettled but does not show anger or rudeness toward Trelawney.
Leads Ron and Hermione with concern toward Hagrid's hut after hearing about Buckbeak's fate, sharing their worry.
Suggests setting Buckbeak free to protect him.
Suggests setting Buckbeak free, showing proactive thinking about helping a friend.
Sits quietly and passively while Hagrid and others discuss the situation without contributing further plans or strategies.
Reluctantly shakes hands with Ron to end hostility.
Does not initiate or encourage the awkward hug between Ron and Hermione but participates.
Responds calmly to getting hit by a stone without lashing out.
Reluctantly shakes hands with Ron to resolve tension despite discomfort.
Responds quickly when a stone bounces off his head and alerts Hagrid.
Looks out the window to identify approaching figures calmly after the incident.
Reaches up and puts his finger to Hagrid's trembling lips, speaks softly to the others, signaling them to be quiet and move carefully.
Yells a warning to Ron to run from the dangerous dog.
Chases after Ron and Scabbers together with Hermione, showing concern and solidarity.
Warns Ron to run when sensing danger from the enormous dog near the Whomping Willow.
Chases after Ron and Scabbers without apparent hesitation, showing quick reaction and concern.
Does not appear to have anticipated the danger fully, as the enormous dog leaps over him and attacks Ron.
Dashes forward to grab Ron’s hands in an attempt to save him from the dog.
Looks directly into Ron’s eyes and reads his mind, showing concern and emotional connection.
Desperately urges Ron to hold on and not let go, showing care and attachment.
Fails to dodge a tree branch while trying to save friends, showing self-sacrifice and focus on others over self.
Fits his glasses promptly after they fall, helping to regain clear vision.
Allows Hermione to grab his shirt and ride a branch together to avoid falling.
Responds to Hermione's thanks with 'Don't mention it.' and provides light with his wand.
Leads Hermione through the dangerous tunnel despite uncertainty.
Shows no hesitation in helping Hermione physically (lifting her up through opening).
Kicks the door open decisively to protect his friends and confront an apparent threat.
Draws his wand with shaking hand, prepared to kill Sirius Black to protect others.
Responds defiantly 'Then it'll be you!' when faced with lethal threat, showing protectiveness over friends.
Harry kicks the door aside confidently and approaches the threat without hesitation.
Draws his wand quickly and prepares to confront Sirius Black despite obvious danger.
Admits openly and firmly that he intends to kill Sirius Black to protect himself and friends.
Wand hand shaking violently when facing Sirius Black, indicating fear and some loss of composure.
Raises his wand angrily and disarms Lupin to confront Sirius Black, showing strong protective instincts toward his deceased parents.
Expresses deep pain and anger but listens to Lupin’s attempt to clarify the truth about his parents’ betrayal.
Displays intense hostility and mistrust toward Sirius Black, accusing him of betrayal without allowing full dialogue initially.
Raises his wand quickly to disarm Lupin, acting with decisiveness and protective instinct.
Accuses Sirius Black angrily without hearing full explanation, letting emotion override judgment.
Eyes flash with pain showing emotional vulnerability during confrontation.
Quickly retrieves his wand and successfully casts 'Expelliarmus' to disarm Snape, demonstrating skill and confidence in a tense situation.
Attacks a teacher impulsively without fully understanding the consequences, causing shock and potential trouble.
Processes the new information about Pettigrew's survival and reveals skepticism about the Marauder's Map, showing critical thinking.
Wants to believe Sirius Black, shows openness and trust despite agony of the situation.
Looks at Ron's agonized face and shows concern.
Demands to see the truth by urging 'Show me' about the rat transformation.
Wants to believe Sirius Black's story despite his desperation; asks to see proof by saying 'Show me.'
Stares intently into Sirius Black’s eyes, showing focus and trying to assess truthfulness.
Relies on Ron and others to act in confrontation rather than taking direct action himself.
Insists on taking Pettigrew to the castle despite knowing he is a dangerous traitor, showing a sense of justice and mercy.
Tells Pettigrew to get off after Pettigrew thanks him, showing firmness and boundary-setting.
Looks away from Pettigrew after Sirius Black calls Pettigrew unworthy, indicating possible restraint or avoidance of cruelty.
Insists on taking Pettigrew to the castle instead of immediately attacking or killing him, showing confident decision-making under pressure.
Recognizes Pettigrew's true nature and the danger he poses, indicating awareness and understanding of the situation.
Refuses to be manipulated by Pettigrew's pleas, maintaining control of the situation.
Refuses to accept revenge or killing Pettigrew, advocates for sparing him to preserve the truth.
Quickly reacts to protect Lupin by disarming Pettigrew despite the danger.
Runs to help Black the dog by hurling a branch to stop the werewolf, showing desperation to protect the animal and others.
Pushes past Snape and dashes into danger to try to save Black.
Plucks a thick branch and accurately hurls it at the werewolf to save Black.
Pushes past Snape and dashes into the night, acting decisively to protect his friend.
Watches stunned as Lupin transforms, showing initial moment of shock but quickly recovers.
Pleads with Professor Lupin to stop when Lupin is about to attack him, showing trust and fear.
Chases after the wounded man-wolf (Sirius), showing concern and urgency.
Stays by Sirius’s side at the lake, attentively watching him despite the cold and danger.
Tries to defend himself and Sirius from approaching Dementors by casting Patronus charm repeatedly.
Harry sees the bright luminous stag protecting against Dementors, showing his inner strength and connection with his past, then quietly observes and processes the situation without panic.
Gently sweeps the hospital curtain aside to reveal Ron, indicating care and a desire to connect with friends.
Shares his vision of his father saving him from Dementors with Hermione calmly, demonstrating trust and openness.
Listens attentively when Hermione explains Sirius's danger, showing concern and engagement.
Perceives and interprets the Patronus as his father's luminous stag protecting him, demonstrating deep understanding and emotional insight.
Reveals having seen his father saving him by sending Dementors away, indicating his awareness of complex magical events and his own experiences.
Asks clarifying questions about the Dementor's Kiss, showing inquisitiveness and desire to fully grasp the danger Sirius is in.
Reacts emotionally and is momentarily silent when Hermione explains the horror of the Dementor's Kiss, showing vulnerability but remaining engaged in the situation.
Passes on the belief that Sirius is innocent, supporting friends' claims despite authority skepticism.
Confidently states Sirius is innocent to Dumbledore despite the danger and uncertainty.
Does not hesitate to stand up for Sirius and assert the truth in front of an authority figure.
Follows Hermione's lead without complaint when she hurries him and insists they must not be seen.
Expresses confusion and a desire for information by asking Hermione to explain what they are doing.
Glances around in confusion but does not show frustration or anger towards Hermione for withholding information.
Follows Hermione without fully understanding the situation but trusts her lead.
Expresses confusion and asks questions about unclear events.
Observes and recognizes his own duplicated presence, showing attention to detail.
Admiring Malfoy's punch despite being an enemy.
Following Hermione's lead and cooperating silently to avoid detection.
Showing wonder and concern for Buckbeak's survival.
Shows concern about confronting Pettigrew despite Hermione's warning, revealing emotional vulnerability and sense of justice.
Accepts Hermione's caution and plans carefully to avoid trouble, showing trust and cooperation.
Reacting with mild pain and a light-hearted complaint when hit by a stone thrown by Hermione, indicating tolerance and good-naturedness.
Harry bows to Buckbeak and attempts to calmly gain its trust by taking the chain, showing confidence and some skill in handling the creature.
Harry reacts to the crow pecking his hand by shouting and waving it away rather than ignoring or more subtly handling the situation.
Harry quickly reacts to the situation by trying to lead Buckbeak away, demonstrating initiative and a proactive attitude.
Works with Hermione to distract Buckbeak and lead him away to protect him from execution.
Looks at Hermione as if she's mad but supports her plan nonetheless.
Expresses eagerness to help save Sirius with Hermione despite uncertainty on how.
Makes a lighthearted joke about Fred and George hearing about Lupin calming the Whomping Willow.
Engages with Hermione in planning to save Sirius despite uncertainty on how to achieve it.
Expresses uncertainty openly when Hermione acknowledges having no idea how to accomplish the plan.
Shares chocolate with Hermione, showing kindness and social awareness.
Recalls and interprets the Patronus he saw, correctly associating it with his father and understanding its significance.
Openly discusses difficult subjects (his dead father) calmly and honestly with Hermione.
Expresses hope and plans for the future (living with Sirius), showing foresight and a proactive mindset.
Wants to free Lupin and offers to help him live comfortably, showing concern for his well-being after suffering years in Azkaban.
Responds promptly to Hermione's warning and appreciates her help, showing cooperation and gratitude.
Focuses on the safety of himself and Hermione by urging immediate movement away from danger.
Reassures Hermione by insisting his father will come to help despite the dire situation.
Focuses on hope and comfort for Hermione in a terrifying moment.
Reflexively stays calm while Buckbeak confronts the werewolf, showing presence of mind in a dangerous situation.
Watches himself futilely attempt to conjure a Patronus while the Dementors' cyclone grows, indicating current inability to perform the necessary magic under pressure.
Continues to hope irrationally that his father will come to help instead of taking direct action himself.
Is transfixed and desperate, unable to grasp the reality of the situation despite Hermione's warnings, showing a lapse in situational awareness and emotional control.
Courageously confronts a dangerous situation by casting a powerful Patronus to protect others from Dementors.
Acknowledges Hermione's earlier insight and shares his internal realization about the time loop and his own ability, showing sincerity and openness.
Draws his wand and confidently casts Expecto Patronum, successfully producing a powerful Patronus that drives away the Dementors.
Waits patiently and remains still until the Dementors have all retreated, showing control and focus.
Correctly reasons that he saw himself conjuring the Patronus before, demonstrating insight and self-awareness.
Expresses desire to go with Sirius despite risks for himself.
Listens attentively and responds sincerely to Sirius' request to trust himself.
Successfully frees Sirius Black by planning and executing time travel with Hermione despite challenges.
Trusts and acts on Sirius Black's advice to rely on inner strength and intuition.
Races with Hermione up the Clock Tower stairs with urgency and focus.
Unhesitatingly confirms Sirius is free to Dumbledore, showing confidence in their actions.
Jumps and expresses shock upon seeing Lupin's condition and departure, showing concern and sincerity.
Accurately identifies Snape as the one who likely revealed Lupin's secret, indicating trustworthiness and attentiveness.
Engages in conversation with Lupin about Patronus, showing respect and a friendly attitude despite difficult circumstances.
Walks softly toward Lupin's office and peeks in, showing caution and awareness.
Immediately recognizes the implication of Lupin's stripped office and questions the resignation, showing awareness and concern.
Expresses shock and surprise at Lupin's resignation, showing some emotional vulnerability but also engagement.
Correctly identifies the Patronus as a stag and connects it to his father, showing understanding and reflection.
Watches the Marauder's Map and processes Lupin's message silently without reacting rashly.
Is mystified and uncertain about the origin of the Firebolt broomstick, but does not panic or jump to conclusions.
Encourages others not to give up on the broom despite initial failure.
Winks at Ron and Hermione to share a private moment of reassurance and camaraderie.
Does not boast or mock others' reactions; instead, he acknowledges the defect calmly.
Recognizes the Hippogriff feather quickly and confidently.
Tests the new Firebolt broom and openly states it might be defective, showing honest critical judgment.
Despite doubting the broom's functionality, confidently winks to friends and then jets off successfully on the Firebolt, demonstrating skill and confidence.
